title: Conservative Charlie Kirk Puts Leftist Students in Their Place Over Vaccines
cleaned_text:
Christian American activist and radio talk show host Charlie Kirk, while recently speaking on the campus of the University of California at Berkeley, was approached by students who asked questions about vaccines, especially the COVID vaccines.

As you can see from this video, Kirk was ready for the challenge.

One student asked Kirk directly if he thought the COVID vaccines were effective.

"Absolutely not," says Kirk, the leader of Turning Point USA, a popular movement among Christian Conservatives. "There could be some evidence that it could be effective in preventing death, but not infection, and certainly not serious infection. There is no evidence of that. (House Speaker) Nancy Pelosi, triple vaccinated, got COVID; Barack Obama, the same. The most vaxxed countries in the world, Israel and Gibraltar, have the highest COVID rates of any country in the world. India, a third-world country and wide distributor of ivermectin, hydroxychloroquine and vitamin D, saw their COVID rates plummet overnight when they started using these cures."

Another student asked Kirk, "You have taken the vaccine, right? What about Trump ..."

"Absolutely not. Not even at gunpoint," Kirk responded. "I believe in hydroxychloroquine, ivermectin, vitamin D, vitamin C, intravenous therapy, ozone therapy and not being fat."

Kirk told the students that he is a free market guy, but that our health care system in America is "so screwed up."

"You're trying to have the government, bought by Big Pharma, break up the pharma that owns them. That won't work. I'm totally in favor of breaking up Pfizer. I hate pharmaceutical companies to the core because they do more damage than good."

At the end of the conversation, one of the students looked at the camera with an apparently smug look and called Kirk out, appearing as if he got the better of the Christian commentator. Watch the video and see what you think.

Shawn A. Akers is the online editor at Charisma Media.
